channel.title: Summative on MPM2DP-0A Summative
channel.description: Recent content in Summative on MPM2DP-0A Summative

item.title: Simplfication of Polynomials
item.description: Simplifications of polynomials involve combining like terms. Example $s\frac{3x+2}{3y-1}$e where $sx=-2$e , and $sy=1$e is: $$s\frac{3x+2}{3y-1}$$e $$s=\frac{4}{2}$$e $$s=2$$e Example The non-permissible value(s) for $s\frac{x^3+1}{y-3}$e is: If $sy-3$e is $s0$e , the answer would be non-permissible. $$sy=3$$e Example The non-permissible value(s) for $$s\frac{2a^2+4a-48}{3a^2+3a-60}$$e $$s=\frac{3(a+6)}{2(a+5)}$$e is: $$sa\ne -5,4$$e

item.title: Operations on Polynomials
item.description: Polynomials can be added by adding each of the like terms in polynomials. Two polynomial expressions (includes functions) are equivalent if: they simplify to give the same expression, or they produce the same graph. Two polynomial functions are not equivalent if: they result in different values when they are evaluated with the same values substituted for the variable(s). How to subtract polynomials To subtract polynomials, rewrite the operation as an addition of negatives: Example $$s(2x^2-x)+(3x^2-2x+3)$$e $$s=5x^2-3x+3$$e Example When are $sxy+xz+yz$e and $sx^2+y^2+x^2$e equivalent?

item.description: Quiz The quiz requires JavaScript to validate the answer(s). body q The SHA-256 hash of the answer is ca978112ca1bbdcafac231b39a23dc4da786eff8147c4e72b9807785afee48bb. Final answer code: enter an answer Explanation exp import { quiz, quizzes } from "/mpm2dp-0a/js/quiz.js"; const page = 'https:\/\/nyiyui.ca\/mpm2dp-0a\/p2\/clue\/'; const quiz_clue_i1 = document.getElementById("quiz-clue-i1"); quiz_clue_i1.addEventListener('input', quiz("clue", 1 , "ca978112ca1bbdcafac231b39a23dc4da786eff8147c4e72b9807785afee48bb", page)); const quiz_clue = [ quiz_clue_i1, ]; quiz_clue_i1.addEventListener('input', quizzes(quiz_clue, document.getElementById("quiz-clue-total"), "clue", page));

item.title: Graphing Quadratic Relations
item.description: All quadratic relations can be made into the form $sy=af(b(x-h))+k$e 1. Then, to graph the relation, apply these transformations in order1: Transformations: For this equation, $y=af(b(x-h))+k$ : Vertical Scaling (using $a$) If $|a| > 1$: vs by $|a|$. Else if $0 < |a| < 1$: vc by $|a|$. Vertical Reflection (using $a$) If $a < 0$: reflect on x-axis. Horizontal Scaling (using $b$) If $|b| > 1$: hs by $\frac{1}{|b|}$.

item.title: Mapping Rule
item.description: The mapping rule for quadratic relations is $s(x, y) \rightarrow (\frac{x}{b}+h)(ay+k)$e . To use it, list 5+ key points from the parent function, then using the mapping notations, determine the new coordinates of the key points, then plot the new points.

item.title: Multiplication of Polynomials
item.description: Multiplication of binomials follow this rule: $$s(a+b)(c+d)=ac+ad+bc+bd$$e This can be easily remembered by using the FOIL method: Multiply the first terms: $sac$e Multiply the outer terms: $sad$e Multiply the inner terms: $sbc$e Multiply the last terms: $sbd$e Example $$s(3x-1)(4-2x)$$e $$s12x-6x^2-4+2x$$e $$s-6x^2+14x-4$$e Since the FOIL method is derived from the distribution rule, for trinomials (e.g. $s(a+b+c)(d+e+f)$e ), we can use the FFMOMFMMOIIMIO method: (this is a joke, please just distribute it on-the-fly)

item.title: Negative and Zero Exponents
item.description: Negative exponents turn the number into its reciprocal, and an exponent of $s0$e is always $s1$e . $$sx^0=1$$e $$sx^-1=\frac{1}{x}$$e Example $$s(\frac{2}{3})^{-2}=(\frac{3}{2})^2=\frac{9}{4}$$e

item.title: Non-Linear Relations
item.description: The independent variable is the variables that is controlled before the trial begins, and the dependennt variable is the one that is measured during the trial. It is usually affected by the independent variable. Non-linear relations do not follow a straight line when graphed. The curve of best fit is a smooth curve drawn to approximate the general path or trend of a scatter plot. Example In the following figure, the blue line is one curve of best fit (4th degree polynomial).

item.title: Practice
item.description: Question 1 Quiz The quiz requires JavaScript to validate the answer(s). Consider $sy=t=0.5(x+1)^2-5$e . Direction of opening (either up or down) The SHA-256 hash of the answer is 75a288c0d6898c5f7b054590845978a82a3ad79fcce3d43ff68a7501e5a91ee9. Stretch or compression factor value The SHA-256 hash of the answer is d2cbad71ff333de67d07ec676e352ab7f38248eb69c942950157220607c55e84. Stretch or compression factor direction (either vertical or horizontal) The SHA-256 hash of the answer is 34da56029403e6f793b86883b3c7205b8dafe06b25a3159f8c06fc87262c1028. $sx$e value of the vertex The SHA-256 hash of the answer is 1bad6b8cf97131fceab8543e81f7757195fbb1d36b376ee994ad1cf17699c464.

item.title: Quadratic Relation
item.description: Quadratic relations are relations whose equatio is in the form $sy=ax^2+bx+c$e where $sa\in \mathbb{R}$e , $sb\in \mathbb{R}$e , $sc\in \mathbb{R}$e , and $sa\ne 0$e . Parabolas are quadratic relations which are U-shaped and symmetrical. The vertex of quadratic relations are where: the curve changes direction, and is either the maximum of minimum (in terms of $sy$e ) point in the relation. The axis of symmetry if the line that divides a digure into 2 congruent parts.

item.title: Zeroes Form
item.description: In the zeroes form, $sy=a(x-r)(x-s)$e , the x-intercepts are $s(r, 0)$e and $s(s, 0)$e , and the vertex is $s(\frac{r+s}{2}, y)$e .

item.title: Practice
item.description: Question 1 Quiz The quiz requires JavaScript to validate the answer(s). Find the factored form of the expression for the area of the shaded region in factored form. Note: the length of the larger side is $s3x+$$e and the length of the shorter side is $sx-2$e . Answer in the form $sA=a(bx+c)(dx+e)$e . $sa$e The SHA-256 hash of the answer is 4b227777d4dd1fc61c6f884f48641d02b4d121d3fd328cb08b5531fcacdabf8a. $sb$e The SHA-256 hash of the answer is 6b86b273ff34fce19d6b804eff5a3f5747ada4eaa22f1d49c01e52ddb7875b4b.

item.title: Binomial Expansion
item.description: The binomial theorem describes how to expand powers of binomials. Example Using the theorem, $s(x+2)^3$e is $s8 + 12 x + 6 x^2 + x^3$e . The $sr$e th coefficient for the $sn$e th is $sn\choose r$e , pronounced “n choose r”. Example The 4th coefficient of $s(3x+8)^6$e is $s6\choose 3$e $s(3x)^38^3$e $s=276480x^3$e

item.title: Factor Perfect Square Trinomials and Difference of Squares
item.description: Difference of Squares $$sa^2-b^2=(a+b)(a-b)$$e Example $$s4x^2-16$$e $$s=(2x-4)^2$$e Perfect Square Trinomials $$sa^2+2ab+b^2=(a+b)$$e $$sa^2-2ab+b^2=(a-b)$$e Example $$s4x^2+20x+25$$e $$s=(2x+5)^2$$e

item.title: Factor Quadratics 2
item.description: To factor trinomials in the form $sax^2+bx+c$e : $$sy+z=ac$$e $$syz=b$$e $$sax^2+bx+c$$e $$s=ax^2+yx+zx+c$$e Example $$s6x^2+17x+12$$e Because $sy+z=ac$e $syz=b$e , $sy=8$e and $sz=9$e . $$s=6x^2+8x+9x+12$$e $$s=2x(3x+4)+3(3x+4)$$e Then, factor by grouping. $$s=(2x+3)(3x+4)$$e

item.title: Factor Quadratics
item.description: To factor trinomials in the form $sx^2+bx+c$e : $$sy+z=c$$e $$syz=b$$e $$sx^2+bx+c$$e $$s=(x+y)(x+z)$$e Example $$sx^4+11x^2+30$$e $$s=(x^2+6)(x^2+5)$$e

item.title: Common Factoring
item.description: Factoring is the opposite of exapanding (what we did so far). To factor a polynomial, group the polynomials by the GCF: $$s8x^2y^2-12x^4y$$e $$s4x^2y(2y^2-3x^2)$$e Example Remember: a GCF does not have to be a monomial. In this case, it is $sx+2$e . $$sa(x+2)+b(x+2)$$e $$s=(a+b)(x+2)$$e You can also factor by grouping terms with a common factor: Example $$s2am+8a+4m+16$$e $$s=(4+m)(2a+4)$$e $$s=2(a+2)(m+4)$$e

item.title: Special Products
item.description: When squaring a binomial, the result becomes: $$s(a+b)^2$$e $$s=a^2+2ab+b^2$$e $$s(a-b)^2$$e $$s=a^2-2ab+b^2$$e Example $$s(3x-2y)^2$$e $$s=9x^2-12xy+4y^2$$e

item.title: Practice
item.description: Question 1 Depends on: p1/u2/t p1/u2/vt $s\triangle ABC$e has vertices $sA(0, 0)$e , $sB(22, 13)$e , and $sC(14, 14)$e . Note: truncate ($s(\lambda x.\lfloor x\rfloor)$e ) to 5 decimal digits and remove prefix and suffix zeroes. For example, $s\frac{1}{3}$e would become $s0.33333$e . Question 1a Quiz The quiz requires JavaScript to validate the answer(s). Determine the circumcentre of $s\triangle ABC$e , in the form $sO(\frac{a}{b}, \frac{c}{d})$e , where $sO$e is the circumcentre.

item.title: Clue
item.description: Quiz The quiz requires JavaScript to validate the answer(s). Determine $sM_{AB}$e where $sA(1, (\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}-\sqrt{3}}-\sqrt{3})^2)$e , and $sB(10, \frac{\sqrt{5}}{\sqrt{5}-\sqrt{19^0}+1})$e , in the form $sM_{AB}(\frac{a}{b}, \frac{c}{d})$e . $sa$e The SHA-256 hash of the answer is 4fc82b26aecb47d2868c4efbe3581732a3e7cbcc6c2efb32062c08170a05eeb8. $sb$e The SHA-256 hash of the answer is d4735e3a265e16eee03f59718b9b5d03019c07d8b6c51f90da3a666eec13ab35. $sc$e The SHA-256 hash of the answer is e7f6c011776e8db7cd330b54174fd76f7d0216b612387a5ffcfb81e6f0919683. $sd$e The SHA-256 hash of the answer is d4735e3a265e16eee03f59718b9b5d03019c07d8b6c51f90da3a666eec13ab35.

item.title: Properties of Circles
item.description: Diameters of circles intersect at the centre of the circle. Chords are line segments that join 2 points on curves (e.g. circles). Right bisectors of chords pass through the centre of circles. There is only one circle that passes through three non-colinear points. A circumference of a triangle is a circle that passes through all three vertices of a triangle.

item.title: Verify Properties of Triangles
item.description: The midpoint, length of line segment, and slope formulas can be used to verify properties of triangles (and sometimes in many ways!). There are some shortcuts for some calculations involving horizontal and vertical lines.

item.title: Properties of Quadrilaterals
item.description: The diagnoals of a parallelogram bisects each other. Joining the midpoint of adjacent sides of any quadrilateral forms a parallelogram. You can use the formulas for lengths, midpoints and slopes to verify properties of quadrilaterals, just like triangles.

item.title: Properties of Triangles
item.description: Circumcentre The circumcentre is the intersection of all of the perpendicular bisectors of the sides of a triangle. It is equidistant from the vertices inside in acute triangles outside in obtuse triangles on $M_c$ where $c$ is the hypotenuse in right triangles Figure Description How to construct the circumcenter of a triangle. Also shows how to construct a circle through given three points. Made with <a href="https://en.

item.title: Circles
item.description: The equation of a circle with: radius $r$ centre $O(h, k)$ is $(x-h)^2+(y-k)^2=r^2$. Other forms of this equation include $r^2=x^2+y^2$ (notice how it’s similar to the Pythagorean theorem). To see whether a point $A$ is inside a circle, calculate $d_{AO}$ where $O=(h, k)$. Whether a point $A$ is inside a circle (including the border) is $d_{AO}\le r$. Example $P(-5, 9)$ is outside the circle with $r=100$: $d_{PO} = \sqrt{5^2+9^2} \approx 10.

item.title: Length of Line Segments
item.description: The distance formula can be used to calculate the length of a line segment on the Euclidean plane. To get the length of a line segment $\overline{\rm AB}$ where $A(x_1, y_1)$, $B(x_1, y_1)$, and $d$ is the length: $d=\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2}$ or $d=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}$ d A B Figure with identifier ls :

item.title: Midpoints
item.description: A midpoint is a point that is equiditant from two points at the end of a line segment. The midpoint of $\overline{AB}$ is $M_{AB}=(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2}, \frac{y_1+y_2}{2})$ where $A(x_1, y_1)$ and $B(x_2, y_2)$. Bisecting lines share their midpoints. For example, in parallelograms, the diagonals bisect each other. A right bisector is a line that bisects another line and intersects it by a $90°$ angle. M A B Figure with identifier mp : A median the line segment joining a vertex of a triangle to the midpoint of the opposite side.

item.title: Radicals
item.description: A radical is an unresolved root, especially one that uses the radical symbol / radix ($\sqrt{~^~}$). Identities Addition: $ a\sqrt{b}+c\sqrt{b}=(a+c)\sqrt{b} $ Multiplication: $ \sqrt{a}\sqrt{b}=\sqrt{ab}, a\le 0, b\le 0 $ Division: $ \frac{\sqrt{a}}{\sqrt{b}}=\sqrt{\frac{a}{b}}, a\le 0, b\le 0 $ Convert to an exponent: $ \sqrt[a]{b}=b^\frac{1}{a} $ Rationalization To rationalize a radical, turn the root into an exponent, and then solve for the exponent: Example Rationalize $\frac{1}{\sqrt{12}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{27}}$: $$\frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}-\frac{1}{3}$$ $$\frac{\sqrt{3}}{6}-\frac{1}{3}$$ $$\frac{\sqrt{3}-2}{6}$$ A conjugate is $a-b$ for $a+b$, and must satify $(a+b)(a-b)=a^2-b^2$.

item.title: Absolute Values
item.description: The absolute value of a value is the distance from 0 on the number line. Since distances are always positive: $|x|\in \{0, \mathbb{Z}\}$ Example To solve abosolute values, split $|x|$ to $-x$ and $+x$. $$|2x+3|\le 4$$ $$2x+3\le 4, -2x-3\le 4$$ $$2x\le 1, -2x\le 7$$ $$x\le \frac{1}{2}, x\ge \frac{-7}{2}$$ $$\frac{-7}{2}\le x\le \frac{1}{2}$$

item.title: Clue
item.description: Quiz The quiz requires JavaScript to validate the answer(s). Determine $f(x)$, where $g(x)=x^2$, and $12+g^{-1}(2f(x)-\frac{5}{2})\ge 3x$ Answer in terms of $f(x)\ge ag(b(x-h))+k$, and round decimals to two places. The answer must match this regular expression: [0-9]+(.[0-9]+)? What is $a$? The SHA-256 hash of the answer is d4735e3a265e16eee03f59718b9b5d03019c07d8b6c51f90da3a666eec13ab35. What is $b$? The SHA-256 hash of the answer is 4e07408562bedb8b60ce05c1decfe3ad16b72230967de01f640b7e4729b49fce. What is $h$?

item.title: Domain and Range
item.description: For any function $g(x)$, get the parent function $f(x)$ and put it into the following form: $$g(x)=af(k(x-d))+c$$ Each parent function has the domain and range (common ones are listed in p4/u8/pfn#common-parent-functions ). To get the domain and range of the function, substitute the $x$ in the domain and the $y$ in the range to $x-d$ and $y-c$. Example To get the domain and range of $(x)$, where $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$, and where $g(x)=\sqrt{x-3}=af(k(x-d))+c$, substitute $x-d$ for $x$ and $y-c$ for $y$: $d=3, d\in \mathbb{R}, x-d=x-3$

item.title: Inequalities
item.description: When both sides of an inequality are multiplied or divided by a negative number, it is “reversed”. $$a\lt b$$ $$x\le y$$ $$-a\gt -b$$ $$-x\ge -y$$ For example, to solve $3x-2\le 2x+1$ and sketch it on the number line: $$3x-2\le 2x+1$$ $$x\le 3$$ an even function 3 Figure with identifier ineq-nl : an even function

item.title: Inverses of Functions
item.description: The inverse of a function reverses the operation that the function does. For example, if $f(x)=x^2$ then $f^{-1}(x)=x^{\frac{1}{2}}$ and therefore $f(f^{-1}(x))=x$. To determine the inverse of a function, reverse the uses of $x$ and $y$. $$f(x)=y=2x^3+4$$ (flip $x$ and $y$) $$f^{-1}(x)=(\frac{x-4}{2})^\frac{1}{3}$$

item.title: Parent Functions
item.description: Even functions satisfy $f(x) = f(-x)$. (notice how even functions have even exponents (i.e. $\frac{n}{2} \in \mathbb{Z}$ in $y=x^n+c$)) For example, $y = |x|$ is even, and therefore it is symmetric on the y axis: an even function Figure with identifier even-func : an even function For example, $f$ is even, where $f(x) = -x^2-2x^2+4$, since $f(-x) = -(-x)^2-2(-x)^2+4 = -x^2+2x^2+4 = f(x)$.

item.title: Practice
item.description: Question 1 Consider this function: $$f(x)=\frac{-27}{(7^{-1})(x-(-3)^3)}$$ p4/u8/dr p4/u8/fmt p4/u8/trans p4/u8/fn p4/u8/inv p4/u8/relfn Question 1a Get the domain and range for $f(x)$, in both set and interval notation. Quiz The quiz requires JavaScript to validate the answer(s). Determine the domain for $f(x)$, in set notation, in the form $D\{x\in\mathbb{R}|x\ne a\}$.

item.title: Transformations of Functions
item.description: For functions of the form $g(x)=af(x-d)+c$, constants $a$, $d$, and $c$ change the shape or location of the graph of $g(x)$. $y=|x|$ Figure with identifier u8l7abs : $y=|x|$ $y=-|x|$ Figure with identifier u8l7rx : $y=-|x|$ Mapping rule: $(x, y) \rightarrow (\frac{x}{b}+h)(ay+k)$ For any function with the form: $g(x)=af(b(x-h))+k$ )

item.title: Functions
item.description: $f(x)$ is pronounced as “f of x”, “f at x”, among many others. It means to replace $f(x)$ with the definition of $f(x)$. For example, if $f(x)=x+1$, $f(1) = 1+1 = 2$ and $f(y) = x+y$. a function a function for use in the example below Figure with identifier func : a function a function for use in the example below

item.title: Notation for Sets
item.description: Set Notation $\{…\}$ defines a set. $(…)$ defines a tuple. $D\{…\}$ defines the domain of a set. $R\{…\}$ defines the range of a set. Example For a relation $S{(0, 1), (2, 3), (4, 5)}$ , $D_S{0, 2, 4}$ , and $R_S{1, 3, 5}$ . This relation is a function. Example For a relation $S{(0, 1), (2, 1), (4, 5)}$ , $D_S{0, 2, 4}$ , and $R_S{1, 1, 5}$ .

item.title: Relations and Functions
item.description: Definitions Let $x$, $y$ represent an independent, and dependent variable, respectively. A relation defines relations between two sets. It can also be represented as a set of ordered pairs with two values, $x$ and $y$. It can also be defined as a referentially transparent and side-effect-free procedure (in computer science). Relation = List[Tuple[complex, complex]] A function is a relation where each value of $x$ corresponds with only one value of $y$.
